Publisher: Helsinki City Tourist Office Pohjoisesplanadi 19 00100 Helsinki 10 Tel. 169 3757 and 174 088 A walking tour in Helsinki ELÄINTARHA - TÖÖLÖ
ELÄINTARHA AND TÖÖLÖ To begin our walking tour of Eläintarha we shall assemble in front of the NATIONAL THEATRE (1). The theatre was built to the plans of Professor Onni Tarjanne in 1902; the frescoes in the parterre are by Juho Rissanen and the paintings on the ceiling by Yrjö Ollila. We can set off on our walking trip by going along the alley on the western side of the theatre, i.e. Läntinen Teatterikuja. On our left we have the administrative building (2) of the NATIONAL BOARD OF RAILWAYS, completed in 1910, and on the right a quadrangular building (3) containing the Minor Auditorium of the National Theatre and the Theatrical School. We continue straight through Kaisaniemi Park, with the fountain pool "Convolvulus" by Viktor Jansson and a bust of the composer Frederik Pacius by Emil Wikström to the right and on the slope to the left a sculpture, "The Elk", by Jussi Mäntynen. If we continue our journey we can see to the left a smoky railway marshalling yard and to the right, in sharp contrast, a verdant park, playing fields, and at the north-eastern corner of the larger of the playing fields, a grave to Major Frederik Granatenhjelm, a leading Freemason who died in 1784. His tombstone bears this inscription: "It doesn't matter whether the world knows who rests here. God knows of his deeds and the wretched bless his memory". The park itself dates from the 19th century and acquired its name from Kajsa Wahllund, who once kept a restaurant popular with students there. The restaurant (4) is now well over a hundred years old. We shall leave it to our left as we proceed to the waterfront and then turn sharp right, noticing on our left one of the BOTANICAL GARDENS OF THE UNIVERSITY of Helsinki (5). The grounds of the Botanical Gardens contain a stone table used by the Freemasons for their meetings. Turning left we cross over the Pitkäsilta or "Long Bridge", which was completed in 1912 and from which one can see Kaisaniemi Bay on the left, while the newer Hakaniemi Bridge is visible on the right. Directly in front of us is Lars Sonck's grey granite KALLIO CHURCH (6), completed in 1912. Its steeple rises to a height of 95 metres above sea level. On continuing our journey we pass the restaurant Sillankorva (7) and the department store Elanto Centrum (8) on the left and on the right the shopping and office complex Meritalo (9). It has a total volume of 100.000 m3 and contains numerous shops, offices and the hotel and restaurant "Merihotelli Cumulus". Thus we will have arrived at the corner of Hakaniemi Square. The flourishing market has had to shrink somewhat to make way for traffic and on the fringes of the square new buildings have arisen in place of the older ones being demolished. If we turn left into Paasivuorenkatu we shall see the small Paasivuori Park containing a statue called "The Boxers" by Johannes Haapasalo (1930) (10). An impressive sight in this district of Siltasaari is the TYÖVÄENTALO ("Workers' House") (11), with its grey granite walls, red roof and steep pinnacles, which was completed in 1908 to the plans of the architect Karl Lindahl. We leave this building on our right as we proceed along the quay called Säästöpankinranta and arrive back at Hakaniemi Square. Directly in front of us we can see the HAKANIEMI MARKET HALL (12), an indoor market, and opposite it a three-pinnacled apartment building, Arena, designed by Lars Sonck. On our right-hand side is the office building belonging to the Postal Bank (13). This modern building was designed by the architect team of Pernaja and Sandell. We now turn sharply to the left to follow the shoreline of the bay called "Eläintarhanlahti". The first building on our right is the circular building "Ympyrätalo" (The Round House) (14), which was designed by Kaija and Heikki Siren. Owned by Kansallis-Osake-Pankki (a bank), this building has 9 overground stories and two underground levels. Its total volume is 125.000 m3. Having passed the Round House, we come to the CITY ADMINISTRATIVE BUILDING (15), which was designed by Heikki Siren. The CITY THEATRE (16), a modern building with a volume of about 100.000 m3 designed by the architect Timo Penttilä is next to the City Administrative Building. On continuing our trip along Eläintarhantie we pass an area containing old wooden villas that are now condemned to demolition. Crossing the railway line, we reach an arm of Töölönlahti Bay with the DEACONESS INSTITUTION (17) on the low hill on the right. The Deaconess Institution was established by Aurora Karamzin in 1867 to train diaconia workers. The present building was completed in 1898. Next we swing to the left along the shoreline. It is really worthwhile to stop for a breather at this point, because the view of the city from this vantage is very pretty, especially when it is lit up in the evenings. On the right is the CITY'S CONSERVATOIRE with its rockeries and greenhouses (18). A bust of H. Bergström by Walter Runeberg (1888) stands in the forecourt. H. Borgström was the person responsible for the establishment of the Eläintarha Nature Park. "Eläintarha" means "zoological gardens" and indeed the gardens were originally intended to become a zoo. Their beautiful condition today is the result of decades of persevering labour. We now arrive at the hill called MÄNTYMÄKI (19), where the labour movement traditionally assembles on May Day. Further to the right is the SWIMMING STADIUM (20) (Jorma Järvi, 1940) and the OLYMPIC STADIUM (21) (Yrjö Lindgren and Toivo Jäntti). The reinforced-concrete walls of the stadium enclose a green pitch surrounded by a black running track. The tower of the stadium is 72 metres in height. The annexe building houses the Sports Museum and the small park in front of the stadium contains a statue of the famous Finnish athlete Paavo Nurmi (Wäinö Aaltonen, 1924). The restaurant on the left called "Töölönranta" is a favourite spot for refreshments because of its beautiful location. The long, low building on the right (22) was designed by Aarne Hytönen and R.V. Luukkonen. It was formerly the Exhibition Hall, but it is now used by the City of Helsinki as a sports hall. If we turn left into Mannerheimintie we pass the Office of the Finnish Sugar Company to our left. In front of its stands the "Sugar Girl" statue (23) (Viljo Savikurki, 1956). The modern office building beside the Finnish Sugar Company's office ws completed in the 1970's. The park on our left with its walking paths and sports fields is HESPERIA PARK (24). This park has been proposed as the site of several cultural buildings. These include FINLANDIA HALL and its congress Wing, which were designed by Alvar Aalto and completed in the 1970's. On the top of a small mound is a statue of the minstrel Larin Paraske by Alpo Sailo (1949). The tall buildings to the right are modern hotels. Further along to the right is the spendid creation of the team of architects Gesellius, Lindgren and Saarinen, the National museum (25), which was completed in 1906. The ceiling of the museum's main hall is decorated with frescoes painted by Akseli Gallen-Kallela and depicting scenes from the Kalevala, Finland's national epic. The small park beside the museum called Matiaksenlehto contains a statue of the Finnish ethnologist M.A. Castren. Behind the little park is the Ostrobothnia building, which belongs to the student fraternity representing students from the district of Ostrobothnia in northwestern Finland. This building (26) was designed by Wäinö Palmqvist and Einar Sjöström. To the left, opposite the National Museum, is Hakasalmi Villa (27) (architect Ernst Lohrman, 1846), the former home of Aurora Karamzin, which she donated to the City of Helsinki. Since 1912, it has been the CITY MUSEUM, which provides visitors with an insight into the life and the ways of the old inhabitants of Helsinki. If we continue our journey we shall pass the PARLIAMENT HOUSE (28) built of grey Kaivola granite according to the plans of Professor J.S. Siren. It was completed in 1930. In the tiny park in front of the Parliament House is a statue of President Kyösti Kallio sculpted by his son, Kalervo Kallio, as well as, in front of the steps, statues of presidents K.J. Ståhlberg and P.E. Svinhufvud by Wäinö Aaltonen. To our left are the railway marshalling yards, which are soon to be transferred to a new location, and the functional MAIN POST OFFICE (29) built of light-coloured bricks and designed by j. Järvi and E. Lindroos. In front of the post office is a bronze equestrian statue of Field Marshal Mannerheim (Aimo Tukiainen). The statue was unveiled on 4.6.1960. Opposite to the post office stands a memorial to President J.K. Paasikivi called East and West (Harry Kivijärvi 1980). (30) The low building in front of the BUS STATION is called "Lasipalatsi" ("Glass Palace") (31). It was designed by the architect team of Kokko, Riihimäki and Revell and completed in 1935 as a temporary business building on the site of the old Turku Barracks, which had been destroyed in 1918. Alvar Aalto prepared a city plan which, when realized, will transform the appearance of these districts all the way from the goods railway station to Maria Hospital. If we proceed towards the RAILWAY STATION through the street called Postikatu, we see the Sokos department store (32) on our right. It was designed by the architect Erkki Huttunen and completed in 1952. And that brings us back to where we started off from, the Railway Square.
